sentences.sentence: I raised the bucket( 桶 ) to his lips. He drank, his eyes closed.
It was as sweet as some special festival treat.
This water was indeed a different thing from ordinary nourishment( 滋养物 ).
Its sweetness was born of the walk under the stars, the song of the pulley( 滑轮 ), the effort of my arms.
It was good for the heart, like a present.

When I was a little boy, the lights of the Christmas tree, the music of the Midnight Mass( 子夜弥撒 ), the tenderness( 温柔 ) of smiling faces, used to make up, so, the radiance( 光彩 ) of the gifts I received.
“The men where you live,” said the little prince, “raise five thousand roses in the same garden—and they do not find in it what they are looking for.”
“They do not find it,” I replied.
“And yet what they are looking for could be found in one single rose, or in a little water.”
“Yes, that is true,” I said.
And the little prince added:
“But the eyes are blind. One must look with the heart . . .”
I had drunk the water.
I breathed easily.
At sunrise the sand was the color of honey.
And that honey color was making me happy, too.
What brought me, then, this sense of grief( 悲痛感 )?
“You must keep your promise,” said the little prince, softly, as he sat down beside me once more.
“What promise?”
“You know—a muzzle( 口套 ) for my sheep . . . I am responsible for this flower . . .”
I took my rough drafts( 草图 ) of drawings out of my pocket. The little prince looked them over, and laughed as he said:
“Your baobabs( 猴面包树 )—they look a little like cabbages.”
“Oh!”
I had been so proud of my baobabs( 猴面包树 )!
“Your fox—his ears look a little like horns( 角 ); and they are too long.”
And he laughed again.
“You are not fair, little prince,” I said. “I don’t know how to draw anything except boa constrictors( 大蟒蛇 ) from the outside and boa constrictors( 大蟒蛇 ) from the inside.”
“Oh, that will be all right,” he said, “children understand.”
So then I made a pencil sketch( 速写画 ) of a muzzle( 口套 ).
And as I gave it to him my heart was torn.
“You have plans that I do not know about,” I said.
But he did not answer me. He said to me, instead:
“You know, my descent( 降落 ) to the earth . . . Tomorrow will be its anniversary( 周年纪念日 ).”
Then, after a silence, he went on:
“I came down very near here.”
And he flushed( 脸红 ).
And once again, without understanding why, I had a queer( 奇怪的 ) sense of sorrow. One question, however, occurred to me:
“Then it was not by chance that on the morning when I first met you—a week ago—you were strolling( 漫步 ) along like that, all alone, a thousand miles from any inhabited( 有人居住的 ) region?
You were on your back to the place where you landed?”
The little prince flushed( 脸红 ) again.
And I added, with some hesitancy( 迟疑 ):
“Perhaps it was because of the anniversary( 周年纪念日 )?”
The little prince flushed( 脸红 ) once more.
He never answered questions—but when one flushes( 脸红 ) does that not mean “Yes”?
“Ah,” I said to him, “I am a little frightened—”
But he interrupted me.
“Now you must work. You must return to your engine. I will be waiting for you here. Come back tomorrow evening . . .”
But I was not reassured( 安心的 ).
I remembered the fox.
One runs the risk of weeping( 哭泣 ) a little, if one lets himself be tamed( 被驯化 ) . . .
Beside the well( 井 ) there was the ruin of an old stone wall.
When I came back from my work, the next evening, I saw from some distance away my little prince sitting on top of a wall, with his feet dangling( 来回摆动 ). And I heard him say:
“Then you don’t remember. This is not the exact spot.”
Another voice must have answered him, for he replied to it:
“Yes, yes! It is the right day, but this is not the place.”
I continued my walk toward the wall.
At no time did I see or hear anyone.
The little prince, however, replied once again:
“—Exactly. You will see where my track begins, in the sand. You have nothing to do but wait for me there. I shall be there tonight.”
I was only twenty meters from the wall, and I still saw nothing.
After a silence the little prince spoke again:
“You have good poison? You are sure that it will not make me suffer too long?”
I stopped in my tracks( 突然停下 ), my heart torn asunder( 成碎片地 ); but still I did not understand.
“Now go away,” said the little prince. “I want to get down from the wall.”
I dropped my eyes, then, to the foot of the wall—and I leaped( 跳跃 ) into the air.
There before me, facing the little prince, was one of those yellow snakes that take just thirty seconds to bring your life to an end.
Even as I was digging into my pocket to get out my revolver( 左轮手枪 ) I made a running step back.
But, at the noise I made, the snake let himself flow easily across the sand like the dying spray( 水花 ) of a fountain,
and, in no apparent( 显然的 ) hurry, disappeared, with a light metallic sound, among the stones.
I reached the wall just in time to catch my little man in my arms; his face was white as snow.
“What does this mean?” I demanded. “Why are you talking with snakes?”
I had loosened( 松开 ) the golden muffler( 厚围巾 ) that he always wore.
I had moistened( 弄湿 ) his temples, and had given him some water to drink.
And now I did not dare ask him any more questions.
He looked at me very gravely( 严肃地 ), and put his arms around my neck.
I felt his heart beating like the heart of a dying bird, shot with someone’s rifle( 步枪 ) . . .

article_info.previous: “我”的水喝完了，于是“我”和小王子在沙漠中行走，寻找水井。最后在第二天黎明，“我”和小王子终于找到了一口井，喝上了水。
article_info.share_words: “And yet what they are looking for could be found in one single rose, or in a little water.” “Yes, that is true,” I said. And the little prince added: “But the eyes are blind. One must look with the heart . . .”

options.en: To draw a muzzle for the sheep.
To draw baobabs for the little prince.
To draw a rose for the little prince.

analysis: 原文提到：“What promise?” “You know—a muzzle for my sheep . . . I am responsible for this flower . . .” 所以答案为A。

question.cn: 为什么小王子看“我”的画时笑了？
question.en: Why did the little prince laugh when he saw "my" drawings?

options.en: Because "my" drawings were true to life.
Because "my" drawings were just not true to life.

options.cn: 因为“我”的画勾起了他的一些美好回忆。
options.en: Because "my" drawings reminded him of  some good memories.

analysis: 从文中的对话可看出：“Your baobabs—they look a little like cabbages.” “Oh!” I had been so proud of my baobabs! “Your fox—his ears look a little like horns; and they are too long.” And he laughed again. 答案应为B。

question.cn: 小王子到达地球有多久了？
question.en: How long had the little prince been on the earth?

analysis: 原文提到：But he did not answer me. He said to me, instead: “You know, my descent to the earth . . . Tomorrow will be its anniversary.” 所以答案为C。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第13天
